title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: But Adam is a common name in the South countrie, and no cne recognized in the bearded smiling manager of Sir Humphrey's Australian mines, that he drove to the station next day, and whom the Master of Hundalee shook so warmly by the hand as he bade him "Godspeed," Adam Nairne, the ex-convict, for all believed him dead, and ever will.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: At the gloaming some of the villagers (auld Sandy one of them) saw the Master of Hundalee — the younger Sir Humphrey  — going toward the "Big House" arm-in-arm with the stranger that alighted from the morning train.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: The Master of Hundalee was a great reader and sat up in a little room, or den, off the library often very late; and this evening he had fallen asleep in his chair, when he was awakened  by a sound in the library.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: The Master of Hundalee proved himself the benefactor of the Nairnes after the taking away of their bread-winner, who had been the Auld Kirk minister; and it was little if anything he left behind him o' the warld's gear to his widow and bairns — two small lads.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: No one knew who did the deed, and no one seemed to care, but none drew a stronger bow on all the Border than Hugh Kerr o' Hundalee.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: Grief and pleasure mingled freely that night at Hundalee ; grief for the fate of the brave Kerr and Armstrong, and joy that Willie Polwarth was still alive to wed the bonnie Mirren.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: On one condition, fair Mirren, can your lover go free — that to-night there will still be a wedding at Hundalee, and I, Scotland's king, be honored in giving away to the Knight of Polwarth the bonniest lass on the Border.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: But they had scarcely dragged him to the tree when, with wild shouts, Hugh o' Hundalee, with forty lancers and the bonnie Mirren galloped through the south yett.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: With lightsome song the happy Polwarth was preparing for his departure to Hundalee when a henchman came running with the tidings that the king with a body o' men had entered the lands o' Polwarth  by the north yett.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: Soon up the roadway rode the Hugh o' Hundalee and his fair sister, never drawing bridle until they entered the courtyard  o' Polwarth.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: Surely a king wars not with women, and his father, as you have told me, loved to listen to the sweet ballads that Miriam Cranstone — my own sweet mother — sang in her father's ha' ere she became the bride o' Hundalee."

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: than the roses and forget-me-nots that lay in half-woven wreaths in the lap o' the gentle mother o' Hundalee.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: And to-night the Polwarth  was to wed your sister! Would that I had been the bearer o' better tidings on such a day to fair Hundalee."

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: "Tut, tut, mother; this is nae day to hae rueful thoughts; you are but dowie wi' the thought o' the handsome Polwarth robbing us o' oor bonnie Mirren ; but ere the Yuletide I will bring ye a daughter as bonnie and as kind as the fair Mirren ; an' tonight,  dear mother, you and I will lead the dancers, and we will show the gallants an' maidens who gather at Hundalee in honour o' my sister's weddin' that the Lady o' Hundalee is as graceful in motion as when — as your own sweet lips hath told us oft — you led the dancers in your father's ha' with Scotland' s heroic king."

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: "Tut, tut, mother; this is nae day to hae rueful thoughts; you are but dowie wi' the thought o' the handsome Polwarth robbing us o' oor bonnie Mirren ; but ere the Yuletide I will bring ye a daughter as bonnie and as kind as the fair Mirren ; an' tonight,  dear mother, you and I will lead the dancers, and we will show the gallants an' maidens who gather at Hundalee in honour o' my sister's weddin' that the Lady o' Hundalee is as graceful in motion as when — as your own sweet lips hath told us oft — you led the dancers in your father's ha' with Scotland' s heroic king."

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: Hither an' thither, in happy mood, ran men an' maidens, with armful o' white heather — the hill flower o' good luck — decorating from base to turret the Castle o' Hundalee ; for 'tis the day that the gallant Polwarth weds the bonnie Mirren.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: Kerr of Hundalee had gone with three brave sons — the youngest but in his teens — with the Scottish army to Flodden plain.
